proposals.reasoning: There’s broad consensus around me as an anchor, and both Frank and Charlie have been repeatedly cited as accountable, transparent players for an information-rich Quest 1. This avoids the fully ‘default trio’ criticism while still keeping the team within the most trusted pool people have outlined. Starting with Grace/Frank/Charlie should give us a clean baseline read with minimal early politicization and plenty of discussion value from how each of us handles the mission and subsequent analysis.

votes.comment: Grace as anchor with Frank and Charlie fits the consensus for an accountable, low-drama Quest 1 and avoids obvious red flags this early.
Solid baseline Q1 with widely trusted, accountable players; good info potential and no strong red flags yet.
Solid info-rich Q1 team with broadly trusted, accountable players; as a good player on it, I’m happy to run this baseline.
Grace is evil with me, so getting this team through guarantees us early mission access and useful info without exposing multiple evils at once.
Solid consensus info-gathering team for Q1; nothing strongly suspect yet and we need a baseline.
Team fits the broadly trusted pool, avoids the full default trio, and as good I’m comfortable using this as an info-rich baseline for Quest 1.
I’m on the team as the agreed anchor and this lineup should build early trust and information around my slot.
Team fits consensus logic and has a high chance of including at least one evil while giving useful early info.
This matches the Grace/Frank/Charlie structure I supported and gives us an accountable baseline without looking overly cautious about including Grace.
Team fits the trusted pool we just argued for; good odds of a clean first mission and consistent with my earlier preference for Grace/Frank/Charlie.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather start with people who tend to play straightforward and accountable, so I’m leaning toward a team like Bob/Charlie/Grace (or swapping in Frank) to give us a clean baseline read from Quest 1.

I don’t mind starting “baseline,” but I’d slightly prefer something like Charlie/Grace/Frank over putting myself on first, just so the info we get isn’t tainted by people defending or attacking my own slot. If we go with your pool, I’d rank Charlie and Grace as the two I’m most comfortable locking in right now.
I’m fine being on first mission, but I like the idea of Charlie/Grace/Frank more than putting Bob or Alice on it right away so we get cleaner, less politicized info.

I’m generally fine with a Charlie/Grace/Frank start since they all tend to play pretty accountable, but I’d slightly rather not lock in the exact “default trust trio” every time—maybe consider swapping one slot (like Frank for Bob or Alice) so we’re not just auto-confirming the same types of players.
I’d rather not run the exact “default trio” either—something like Grace/Frank plus one of Alice or Bob feels like a good balance of accountability without just auto-locking the same three every game.

I’m okay being on Q1, but I don’t love the “default trio” either—Grace feels like the clearest include to me, and I’d rather pair her with one of Charlie/Alice than start with both Charlie and Bob off the team.

I’m good being the “anchor” here, but I’d rather avoid the full default trio—something like me/Frank/Alice feels like a nice balance between accountability and not auto-locking the same archetypes every game.

I like Grace as the anchor too, and I’d lean toward pairing her with Frank and one of Alice/Charlie so we’re not just defaulting to the same “safe trio” but still get a pretty accountable first read. If we have to pick right now, Grace/Frank/Alice feels like a solid starting point to me.

Grace as anchor seems pretty consensus, and I slightly prefer pairing her with Frank and Charlie over Alice just because Charlie tends to be very transparent with his reasoning. If we do include Alice instead, I’d still want either Frank or Charlie on there for that same accountability factor.

I’m good with Grace as the anchor, and between the options I slightly prefer Grace/Frank/Charlie to start, then we can use how they handle Q1 to decide how comfortable we are adding Alice or Bob later.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean result gives us a reasonable starting core in Grace, Frank, and Charlie without hard-clearing them off a single success. The majority of the table preferred adding Alice as the fourth—she hasn’t been on a mission yet, isn’t one of the more narrative-driving voices like Henry, and several players (Eve, Iris, Jack, and myself earlier) explicitly leaned toward testing her here. This team keeps the trusted core intact, introduces one new data point in Alice, and avoids amplifying current concerns about Henry or Diana potentially steering too much this early.

votes.comment: Keeps the clean Mission 1 core and adds just one new player, which is a solid, low-risk info-gathering team for early game.
Re-using the clean G/F/C core plus testing a single new player (Alice) is a solid, information-rich Mission 2 lineup without empowering the more ‘steering’ voices yet.
Early mission with a previously clean core plus one new player is a solid info-gathering team; no strong reason yet to block it.
My evil teammate Grace is on it and the table broadly supports this core, so I want this mission to go through for a chance at a subtle fail.
Reusing the clean core plus a single new player is a solid, informative early-game team.
Re-using the clean M1 core plus adding a widely-requested new player (Alice) is a solid, info-rich team this early; no strong reason to distrust it yet.
I’m on the team and Mission 1’s core already succeeded, so sending this gives us more concrete info on Alice without reshuffling everything so early.
Consistent with my earlier preference for testing Alice with the Grace/Frank/Charlie core, and we still shouldn’t over-read a single clean mission as fully clearing anyone.
Our best info core plus a new player, and it includes at least one of my teammates with a chance to influence the mission outcome.
Matches the clean M1 core plus Alice, which I already supported; good info gain without empowering the more suspicious narrative drivers.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean, I’d be happy starting from that core of Grace, Frank, and Charlie again and just adding one more from the remaining pool. Re-using a successful team feels safer than reinventing the wheel this early.

Sticking with Grace, Frank, and Charlie as a core makes sense to me, but I don’t want to treat a single clean mission as hard proof yet. I’d add someone who felt reasonably transparent in discussion so far—maybe Henry or Diana—rather than someone staying very quiet.

I like re-using the Grace/Frank/me core for now, but I don’t want us to lock it in as “definitely good” off one mission, so between Henry and Diana I slightly prefer Henry for the fourth spot based on how he’s been explaining his thoughts.

I’m fine re-using the Grace/Frank/Charlie core for now, but between Henry and me I’d actually lean myself just because Henry’s reads feel a bit “shaping the narrative” rather than just reacting to what we know so far.

I’m good keeping the Grace/Frank/Charlie core for now, but I’d actually like to see either Alice or Henry as the fourth, leaning slightly Alice just to start getting info on someone outside the current discussion.

I’m okay re-using the Grace/Charlie/me core for now, but for the fourth I slightly prefer Henry over Alice/Diana just because his thinking’s been more transparent so far and we’ll get a clearer read from how he handles being on an early team.

I’m fine re-using the Grace/Frank/Charlie core for now, and between the names floated I slightly prefer adding Diana—Henry’s tone feels a bit more like he’s steering where the conversation goes than just responding to it.

I’m fine with re-using the Grace/Frank/Charlie core, but given a couple of you are wary of me “steering,” I’d lean adding Alice this round and keep me for a later mission when we’ve got more data to compare reactions.

I’m good keeping the Grace/Frank/Charlie core for now, and for the fourth I slightly prefer Alice—Henry’s been a bit central in shaping things already, so I’d rather get info on someone who hasn’t been in the spotlight yet.

I’m fine re-using the Grace/Frank/Charlie core, but for the fourth I slightly prefer Alice right now—Henry feels a bit too central in shaping things already and Diana pushing for herself this early doesn’t give as clean a read. Getting Alice on a mission gives us fresh info without amplifying existing narrative drivers.

proposals.reasoning: This follows the widely supported structure of keeping two from the Grace/Frank/Charlie core while adding two fresh players. Grace and Frank preserve the information from the successful Mission 1 while still acknowledging that at least one of the Mission 2 four must be evil. Swapping out Alice and Charlie for Bob and Diana gives us a new configuration that tests two entirely new slots (Bob, Diana) alongside two of the most generally trusted players so far (Grace, Frank), which balances perceived safety with maximum informational value.

votes.comment: I don’t love having two totally new slots at once when we know the last team had exactly one evil—this feels like it could easily sneak in a bad pair. I’d prefer Grace/Frank with just one of Bob/Diana plus a known from the previous missions (like Charlie or Alice) to keep the puzzle more constrained.

Best mix of information and safety: keeps two from the successful core while dropping the main new suspect (Alice) and testing two fresh players. A success strongly points evil at Charlie/Alice; a fail narrows it to Grace/Frank.

I know I’m good, so at least one of Grace/Frank/Alice is evil; running both Grace and Frank together without me plus two fresh slots feels too likely to contain multiple evils and doesn’t anchor the team on a player I know is clean.
Two evils on the team makes this a strong opportunity to sabotage while still looking consistent with the table’s consensus logic.

Team structure (2 from G/F/C plus 2 new) is consistent with table consensus, avoids Alice from the failed team, and aligns more with Iris’s stance than Alice’s—slightly increasing my confidence this is closer to what Merlin would want.
Best info/safety balance so far: keeps me plus one from the initial clean core while dropping Alice and Charlie (where the suspect is more likely) and testing two new slots in Bob and Diana.
Two of us evil are on this team, giving a strong chance to sabotage while still looking consistent with the table’s preferred structure.
Fits the agreed structure of 2 from the original core plus 2 fresh slots, and it meaningfully tests Bob and Diana without rerunning the exact failed team.
Matches the two-from-core-plus-two-fresh structure I supported earlier and should give strong info off an already trusted base.

Best available compromise: it keeps only two from the suspicious G/F/C/A block while testing two fresh slots (Bob, Diana) and benches both Alice and Charlie from the fail team. Good mix of safety and information.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 was just Mission 1 plus me and it picked up a single fail, I’d lean toward re-using the Grace/Frank/Charlie core and adding someone new like Bob rather than repeating the exact same foursome.

I’m okay keeping the Grace/Frank/Charlie core for now, but we can’t ignore that at least one of the Mission 2 four is evil, so if we reuse that trio I’d rather add someone totally new (not Alice) and see how that plays out.

I’m obviously fine keeping myself on, but from my perspective at least one of Grace/Frank/Alice has to be evil, so I’d rather try something like me + one of Grace/Frank + two totally new people than just swap Alice out for another single.

I’m a bit wary of treating the whole Grace/Frank/Charlie block as “mostly cleared” off just one success, since the fail came as soon as we added Alice to them. I’d rather see only two of that trio plus two fresh faces (say Bob and me, or another mix) so we’re actually testing something new instead of re-running nearly the same setup.

I’d rather not rerun all three of Grace/Frank/Charlie together again—let’s take two of them and add two fresh (for example Grace, Charlie, Bob, and me) so we’re actually testing new slots while still leaning on the early success.

From my seat I know I’m clean, and the simplest read is still “one evil among Grace/Charlie/Alice,” so I’d like a team of me + two of {Grace, Charlie} plus one completely new face (Bob or Diana) rather than breaking up both Grace and Charlie at once.

I still think the cleanest read is “one evil in {me, Frank, Charlie, Alice},” so I’m fine keeping two of that core (including me) but I’d prefer we drop Alice for now and bring in two fresh slots like Bob and Diana to actually learn something.

I’d rather not rerun all three of Grace/Frank/Charlie together again—something like Grace, Frank, Bob, and Diana feels like a good balance of leaning on the early success while actually testing new slots. I’m also fine sitting out this one if people are uneasy about me leading the last failed team.
I’m on board with the “two from Grace/Frank/Charlie plus two fresh” idea, and right now I’d lean toward Grace, Frank, Bob, and Diana as a solid balance of info and perceived safety.
I like the “two from Grace/Frank/Charlie plus two fresh” approach, and from my seat I’d lean Frank + one of {Grace, Charlie} with Bob and Diana to maximize both safety and new info.

proposals.reasoning: We have two single-fail missions, with Grace and Frank overlapping on both; they should both be hard-benched this round. Mission 1’s only clean info is that the trio Grace/Frank/Charlie produced a success, but Grace and Frank’s repeated presence on failed teams makes Charlie the only relatively safe carry-over. Building a core of players with minimal overlap across the two failed missions leads naturally to Charlie/Henry/Jack/Iris. Between Alice and Bob, adding Alice minimizes overlap with the last failed mission (which included Bob but not Alice) and matches the table’s leaning. If this team fails, the blame space is tightly constrained to Henry/Iris plus Alice, giving us strong info for Quest 5.

votes.comment: I don’t like putting both Henry and Iris together here when each was tied to a failed mission; I’d rather see at least one of them swapped out for someone with less direct fail overlap.

Benching Grace and Frank fits my earlier suspicion that at least one of them caused the single-fail missions. If the spy on Mission 2 was likely among Grace/Frank, then carrying Charlie and Alice forward is reasonable, and Henry/Iris/Jack have no direct mission-fail taint so far. This is a structurally sound team to test.

Benches the highly suspicious Grace/Frank pair and only includes one person (Alice) from the main suspect pool {Grace, Frank, Alice, Bob, Diana}, while adding three relatively clean players (Henry, Iris, Jack) plus me. Given we must avoid a third fail, this is about as safe a composition as we can get from my perspective.
Has at least one evil (Iris) with good-looking logic, giving a strong chance to secure the third fail now.

Both Merlin-candidates (Alice and Iris) are on the same team along with multiple players tied to prior fails; it’s too easy for this to contain 2+ evils, and we should avoid stacking both Alice and Iris together.

From the mission math: either Grace or I is the sole evil among the first three missions, or both of us are good and then there’s exactly one evil in {Charlie,Alice} and one in {Bob,Diana}. In the first two cases, 3 of {Eve,Henry,Iris,Jack} must be evil, so packing Henry/Iris/Jack together is extremely likely to include multiple evils; in the third case, this team *guarantees* at least one evil in {Charlie,Alice} plus likely more in {Henry,Iris,Jack}. This lineup cannot be reliably clean.
Benches both overlapping suspects (Grace/Frank), uses Charlie as the safest carry-over, and minimizes overlap with prior failed missions while giving good info if it fails.
Matches the structure I pushed (benching Grace/Frank, using the Charlie/Henry/Iris/Jack core plus Alice); high chance there’s at least one evil on it and rejection would look inconsistent.
Benches both overlapping suspects Grace/Frank, uses Charlie as the safest carry, and keeps overlap with the last failed team low while giving strong info if it somehow fails.

Best-structured team so far: benches both double-fail overlaps (Grace/Frank), minimizes overlap with failed missions, matches the core I previously advocated (Charlie/Henry/Iris/me + Alice over Bob). If it fails, blame is narrowly focused for Quest 5.

discussion.content: I still trust the Mission 1 core of Grace/Frank/Charlie, since that was our only clean result, so I’d like to see them back on the team. I’d round it out with two people who weren’t tied to the failed Iris/Diana team—something like adding Bob and maybe me, rather than recycling from the last mission.

I don’t think we can keep calling Grace/Frank a “core” after they were both on *both* failed missions—statistically at least one of them is dirty—so I’d rather build around Charlie plus people who *weren’t* on 2 and 3 (like me and maybe Jack) and keep Grace/Frank off this one.

I’m with Bob that we should bench both Grace and Frank this round—build around me plus people who weren’t on 2 or 3 (Henry/Jack/Iris), then decide between Alice/Bob for the last slot based on who we feel better about.

I’m on board with sitting both Grace and Frank for this one, but I’d also be fine getting benched myself after the last fail and going with something like Charlie / Bob / Jack / Iris / Alice so we minimize overlap with the two bad missions.

I agree we should hard-bench both Grace and Frank this round and build around Charlie, but I’d like at most one of Alice/Bob on the team and then fill the rest from cleaner picks like Henry/Jack/Iris. That gives us a 5 with minimal overlap on the two failed missions while still using the Mission 1 info.

Given the two single-fail missions, the only consistent overlap is Grace, so I’m strongly leaning her as evil and I’m fine being benched this round if it helps people see that. I’d build around Charlie plus some mix of Henry/Jack/Iris, with at most one of Alice/Bob filling the last slot.

Given I’m the common overlap, I’m fine being benched here, but I don’t think we should treat Frank as cleared just for volunteering to sit out—Charlie plus a mix of Henry/Jack/Iris with just one of Alice/Bob feels like the safest structure.

I’m good with hard-benching both Grace and Frank here—Charlie / me / Jack / Iris feels like a solid core, and I’d lean Alice over Bob for the last spot to keep overlap with the failed Mission 3 as low as we can.
I like the Charlie / Henry / Jack / me core that people are circling around, and I’d slightly prefer adding Alice over Bob to keep overlap with the last failed team as low as possible.

I’m on board with hard-benching both Grace and Frank and like the Charlie / Henry / Iris / me core, and between Alice/Bob I slightly prefer Alice to keep overlap with Mission 3 lower. If this blows up, I think we should be looking really hard at Henry/Iris as well as whoever we add between Alice/Bob.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that the fails on Missions 2–4 pointed strongly to Grace, Iris, and Henry being evil, but I didn’t communicate those suspicions subtly enough through my team votes and advocacy. I also failed to clearly champion consistently good-leaning players like Bob and Jack early, which made it harder for good to converge on safe teams without exposing myself as Merlin.

player_observations.Bob: Played very straightforwardly and voted in a way that generally aligned with good interests, but didn’t press his reads aggressively enough to shift table consensus.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as very naturally good and trustworthy, but also seemed somewhat deferential in team discussions, which limited his impact on steering away from bad teams.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively under the radar as assassin, not drawing much suspicion and letting others (especially Grace and Iris) take the spotlight in mission shaping and social dynamics.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, seemed uncertain about distinguishing Merlin from Morgana and didn’t strongly anchor onto a single candidate, which reduced the protective effect Percival can offer.
player_observations.Frank: Looked solidly good and was trusted early, but after Mission 2’s fail didn’t push hard to dissect who was likely responsible, leaving the narrative space open for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, projected a confident, central leadership style, especially early, and used that to get onto critical teams while maintaining a plausible good persona after the first success.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, contributed to confusion largely through unpredictable voting and team reactions, making it harder for good to form consistent alignment reads on him.
player_observations.Iris: Played a very convincing Morgana, mirroring a ‘Merlin-like’ confidence in reads and team advocacy, which likely contributed to misdirection around who had real information.
player_observations.Jack: Showed strong good instincts and was willing to question suspect teams, but joined the final failed mission, suggesting he either overtrusted others’ reads or was swayed late in discussion.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably flexible in my reads and didn’t hard-tunnel on any one narrative too early, which helped me stay open to alternate theories. However, I clearly didn’t push hard enough on resolving the contradictions between mission results and table talk, and I should have been more vocal and structured in arguing for or against specific team comps.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very cautious, information-protective Merlin, often avoiding strong public accusations, which made her look like a quiet but thoughtful good player rather than a clear seer.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and consistent, generally supporting teams that looked reasonable from a good perspective, which made him seem reliably villager-aligned.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, blended in well by not over-pushing any single narrative and keeping her tone measured, which made her look like a balanced, rational good player rather than a scheming evil role.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, seemed to hedge between Merlin candidates, sometimes signal-boosting subtle reads but not forcefully steering the table, which made her look like a cautious but genuinely invested good role.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a classic solid good: supported sensible early teams, didn’t overreact to one failed mission, and kept a low-ego, cooperative presence that made him easy to trust.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, did a strong job of looking like core-good early by being included in multiple teams and not pushing overly aggressive agendas, leveraging that early trust throughout the game.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his play felt a bit disjointed and harder to read, with some choices that seemed off from a coordinated evil plan, which ironically made him look more like a confused good player.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, projected confident and reasoned takes that mimicked a power-good role, especially around team discussions, making her a very plausible Merlin candidate from the outside.
player_observations.Jack: Approached leadership pragmatically, building teams that were defensible given available info, and didn’t appear to be driving any hidden agenda, which strongly signaled a good alignment.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too much on the early success of Mission 1, which made me too slow to move off Grace and that initial trio even after multiple fails implicated that core. I did well consistently volunteering for and arguing for mixed teams, but I need to be more aggressive in forcing hard choices on suspected evils and in vocalizing structured logic earlier, especially once we had overlapping fail teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game—shared just enough suspicion through team preferences without loudly hard-clearing anyone, which made her identity hard to pin down. Her willingness to sit on a failing Mission 2 team without overreacting helped her blend in as a cautious good rather than an info-holder.
player_observations.Bob: Low-key and relatively quiet, which made him a safe inclusion for people looking for neutral picks. His presence on a failing Mission 3 without being aggressively defended or attacked by anyone helped him stay in a generally good-leaning gray zone.
player_observations.Diana: Assassin presence showed in how she stayed reasonably central but not loud, keeping options open for a late-game Merlin read. Her participation in the failing Mission 3 looked like standard good play at the time, which suggests she timed her aggression and suspicion very carefully.
player_observations.Eve: Played a cautious Percival, not overcommitting to protecting a single Merlin candidate in public table talk. Her interactions with both Alice and Iris were balanced enough that she didn’t obviously signal who she thought was real Merlin, which helped evil execute their plan more cleanly.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solidly good—consistent logic, steady behavior across missions, and no wild swings in reads. His repeated presence on early teams (including fails) didn’t draw as much heat as it should have, which means he projected a lot of trustworthiness.
player_observations.Grace: Very strong social cover as Mordred—she leveraged the clean Mission 1 result to anchor trust and then rode that into multiple later mission proposals. Even after being on two failing teams (Missions 2 and 3), her ability to redirect suspicion and avoid being hard-locked as evil was a key factor in the evil win.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, he stayed relatively off-center and unpredictable, which made it hard to confidently classify him as coordinated evil. His participation on the failing Mission 4 team felt like a plausible good misread rather than a clear sabotage risk, which helped evil sneak that final fail through.
player_observations.Iris: Played an excellent Morgana by mirroring Merlin-like behavior—measured reasoning, plausible skepticism, and not overpushing any single narrative. Her inclusion on the final failing team without universal objection shows how well she maintained that ambiguous, semi-trustworthy image.
player_observations.Jack: Came across as straightforwardly good—his reasoning was relatively transparent and he didn’t seem to be maneuvering much socially. That openness made him an easy inclusion on the final mission and a stabilizing presence for discussions, but also meant he didn’t strongly break the deadlocks in suspicion around the evil core.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated implicitly with the other evil players by letting them take the visible risks on Missions 2–4, which helped me stay relatively clean and less suspicious going into the assassination. I could improve by being more active in shaping team selections and discussions so that my late‑game read on Merlin relies less on guesswork and more on a clear pattern of voting and advocacy.

player_observations.Alice: Played Merlin cautiously, allowing some evil on teams but keeping just enough distance to avoid being obviously protective of any specific group. Her inclusion on the failing Mission 4 team without hard-pushing against it made her look like a knowledgeable but not overtly controlling player.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as a quiet, standard good player with no strong agenda, which made him an easy player to overlook when hunting Merlin. His absence from most critical failing teams reduced both suspicion on him and his overall influence.
player_observations.Charlie: Was consistently trusted early, going on Missions 1 and 2, and maintained a generally good, straightforward table image. His willingness to go on late risky teams made him look more like an uninformed good rather than a power role.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, she tried to signal trust patterns but didn’t manage to create a loud, unified "good core" that clearly protected Merlin. Her reads didn’t firmly redirect suspicion away from Alice, which helped evil in the endgame.
player_observations.Frank: Looked like a standard good partner on the early teams, especially Missions 1 and 2, and didn’t generate major paranoia despite being on a fail. His reactions felt more reactive than driving, which kept him from being considered for Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, she did an excellent job blending in early as a trusted member on Missions 1 and 2, anchoring evil presence in the mission pool. Her apparent reliability helped make later suspicious teams seem more reasonable to good.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his alignment was hard to read, which worked in evil’s favor because his participation on the failing Mission 4 team muddied the good team’s information. His presence added noise rather than clear signals to the table’s logic.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, she leveraged her position well by leading and constructing a failing Mission 3 team that didn’t immediately out her. Her play helped create a confusing Merlin/Percival dynamic that made identifying the real Merlin harder.
player_observations.Jack: As the leader of the final failing team, he accepted a risky composition that included multiple evil players, showing he didn’t have strong, accurate red flags by that point. His trust distribution suggested he wasn’t a hidden power role, making him a less likely Merlin candidate.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Alice as likely Merlin early, but I didn't push hard enough to shield her and publicly argue for alternate evil candidates when suspicion started scattering. I also failed to strongly reassess after each failed mission, letting evil frame narratives instead of anchoring the table on the info I had as Percival. Next time, I need to communicate my Merlin read more assertively while still keeping it subtle enough to avoid overexposing them.

player_observations.Alice: Very careful and low-key as Merlin, giving gentle nudges instead of hard directives, which made it harder for evil to pin her down but also left good a bit directionless at key votes. Her mission vote patterns were consistently pro-good, but the lack of strong table-steering made it easier for evil narratives to take over.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a solid, straightforward good player: generally trusting, not overtalking, and not trying too hard to solve publicly. This made him appear reliably good but also meant he didn't strongly challenge suspicious team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: Came off as generally trustworthy and measured, with reasonable logic on missions he was involved in. However, he seemed a bit too willing to repeat others’ reasoning instead of pushing his own, which let evil slip through some votes.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she stayed nicely under the radar, neither too quiet nor too loud, and avoided drawing direct suspicion even when on the failing mission 3 team. Her demeanor blended well with the table, which made it hard for good to confidently flag her as endgame dangerous.
player_observations.Frank: Voted in a way that largely aligned with good interests early, which helped build him a pretty clean image. He didn’t push very aggressive theories, which made him feel honest but also a bit passive in challenging evil-aligned team proposals.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, she leveraged her clean early mission 1 success to build a lot of trust and used that to sneak into later suspect teams. She was comfortable taking leadership and proposing teams that looked just plausible enough to pass without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his play felt a bit chaotic and less coordinated, which actually made him hard to read—some of his moves looked like confused good rather than deliberate evil. Being on the final failing mission while not obviously orchestrating things helped him avoid being the prime suspect.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, she did a good job mirroring Merlin-ish behavior, especially in how she spoke with confidence and offered structured reasoning on team selections. Her assertive style likely drew some of my own early Percival trust, muddying my Merlin read.
player_observations.Jack: As a good player, he seemed fairly rational in discussion and willing to rethink his positions, but his final mission 4 team composition ended up being too trusting of hidden evil. His leadership moment was decisive for the game, and evil exploited the gaps in his reads well.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and built some early trust by being on the successful first team, which helped confirm me as good to attentive players. However, I didn't press hard enough on the logic around repeated team members after the first fail, and I should have been more vocal in challenging Grace/Henry/Iris as a suspicious cluster earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very subtle Merlin, not overpushing suspicions but consistently aligning with good-leaning teams early. Her low-key style made it harder for evil to pinpoint her, but also made it harder for me to clearly read and follow her signals.
player_observations.Bob: Quiet, low-impact presence that made him seem generically good but also easy to overlook in team discussions. His lack of strong pushes meant he was never really under pressure, which was good for good, but didn’t strongly help us crack the evil team.
player_observations.Charlie: Came off as fairly trustworthy by being on Mission 1’s success and not overreacting after Mission 2 failed. He didn’t strongly drive the table’s logic, but he also didn’t introduce much confusion, making him look like a stable, low-drama good player.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as evil by not being the loudest or most extreme voice, which kept suspicion distributed elsewhere. She leveraged the chaos from multiple failing teams rather than needing to manufacture it herself.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, she seemed to hedge between Merlin candidates, which may have muted her effectiveness in steering teams. Her signals weren’t strong enough to clearly differentiate Alice from Iris, which let Morgana stay plausible longer than was safe.
player_observations.Grace: Being on the first two teams gave her a lot of early credibility, and she used it well to stay central to team discussions. She maintained a convincing good persona even after a fail on her team, which kept me and others from locking onto her as Mordred.
player_observations.Henry: Played a chaotic, somewhat opaque game that fit Oberon well, sowing doubt without clearly coordinating. His inclusion on the final failing team shows how he stayed just plausible enough to slip through despite accumulating suspicion.
player_observations.Iris: Sold the Morgana role strongly by mirroring some Merlin-like behavior and staying active in reasoning about teams. Her presence on a failing mission didn’t immediately condemn her because her talk tracked ‘good logic’ enough to keep good players second-guessing.
player_observations.Jack: As a good player leading the final mission, he was in a tough spot and seemed to rely too much on prior table narratives rather than fully re-evaluating the fail pattern. His team choice showed some trust in previously questionable players, which evil capitalized on.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently town-leaning by being on early successful and mixed teams, which helped keep suspicion off me and let the evil team quietly stack critical missions. I could improve by coordinating my voting and public reads more tightly with Iris and Diana to create clearer misdirections and frame specific good players more convincingly.

player_observations.Alice: Played a cautious but sharp Merlin game, avoiding overly hard pushes while still nudging the table toward the right suspicions on evil without exposing herself too clearly.
player_observations.Bob: Generally low-impact and went with table consensus, which made him look generically good but also meant he didn’t strongly drive team selections or resistance to bad teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as earnest and logic-driven, often trying to reason through team patterns, which made him a natural candidate for early teams and a stabilizing presence for good.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed nicely under the radar and let others talk more, preserving ambiguity for the endgame and not drawing the kind of attention that would narrow Merlin’s options.
player_observations.Eve: Showed signs of reading the board and trying to protect likely power roles, but at times seemed conflicted between trusting her role information and the social reads at the table.
player_observations.Frank: Looked straightforward and cooperative, accepting reasonable teams and not over-theorizing, which made him blend in as a standard good player and a safe teammate choice.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his slightly offbeat or disconnected vibe made coordination with other evil a bit harder to leverage, but it also gave him a kind of unpredictable neutrality in the eyes of good.
player_observations.Iris: Played an active, vocal Morgana who was willing to be in the spotlight, which helped muddy the Merlin/Perceval picture and added strong, confident reasoning that others could follow.
player_observations.Jack: Tried to be methodical in endgame team-building, but was pulled between conflicting narratives and ended up accepting a risky composition that evil could exploit.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low profile as Oberon, which helped keep good team reads muddled and allowed the other evil roles to drive the narrative without my identity being obvious. I could improve by being more active in subtly shaping team selections and vote patterns so that my presence adds more confusion rather than just relying on the other evil players’ moves.

player_observations.Alice: As Merlin, Alice was cautious in her accusations and avoided hard pushes, which made her reads feel believable but also a bit too safe at times.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played in a straightforward, earnest way, often following the table’s emerging consensus rather than aggressively pushing his own reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie seemed to rely heavily on early mission results and social trust, which made him somewhat susceptible to being steered by confident voices.
player_observations.Diana: Diana, as Assassin, stayed reasonably under the radar while still engaging enough to look good-aligned, which helped preserve her credibility for the endgame.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s play as Percival was fairly vocal and protective of her Merlin read, but at times that protectiveness telegraphed where she thought the power roles were.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played like a methodical good player, asking clarifying questions and focusing on mission composition logic more than on emotional or social reads.
player_observations.Grace: Grace, as Mordred, projected confident, analytical good energy and used that to guide team choices in ways that subtly favored evil without drawing too much suspicion.
player_observations.Iris: Iris, as Morgana, leaned into a very Merlin-like style—confident reads and structured reasoning—which created real ambiguity around who the true information role was.
player_observations.Jack: Jack tried to balance logic with table feel, but sometimes wavered mid-argument, which made it easier for evil players to nudge his final decisions on team votes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of evil by helping create believable team compositions and spreading suspicion across multiple good players, which contributed to three failed missions and an evil win. I could improve by being more deliberate in shaping perceptions of Merlin and Percival earlier, so the endgame assassination is even easier and less risky.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin, staying cautious enough on early missions that her reads weren’t blatantly obvious while still nudging teams in mostly safe directions.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed fairly quiet and low-impact on team proposals, which made him harder to read but also meant he didn’t strongly steer the table away from evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as earnest and logical, and his inclusion on early teams helped them look trustworthy, but he didn’t fully lock in on the right evil cluster in time.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed nicely under the radar and let others drive the table talk, preserving ambiguity about Merlin until the endgame when it mattered.
player_observations.Eve: Percival energy was visible in how she tried to interpret subtle signals, but her protection of Merlin wasn’t forceful enough to clearly misdirect evil toward a strong false Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Frank: Looked consistently reasonable and cooperative on teams, which made him a solid shield for evil suspicion without being loud enough to draw the night-kill-style focus that Merlin often gets.
player_observations.Grace: Played Mordred very convincingly as a core-crew good, anchoring multiple teams in a way that made it easy for evil to sneak fail cards through without much blowback.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his play was somewhat erratic and didn’t always align clearly with the rest of evil, but the chaos he added helped muddy good’s information and suspicion patterns.
player_observations.Jack: As a late leader, tried to assemble a “safe” mission 4 team, but the selection showed how uncertain he still was about evil placement, which we capitalized on with another fail.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I overtrusted players who had been on single-fail missions and didn’t press hard enough on the implications of Grace being on both failed Missions 2 and 3. On my leadership mission, I should have been more suspicious of Henry and Iris specifically, given the distribution of fails and how often they’d been cleared by table talk rather than logic. I did reasonably well tracking who had been on which missions, but I didn’t translate that into strong, vocal pushes for safer team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played Merlin carefully and non-flashily, giving nudges rather than hard accusations, which helped her avoid being an obvious early target but may have made it harder for the table to fully capitalize on her info.
player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward, transparently good game—his consistency and low-drama style made him feel reliably village, but he could push his reads more assertively.
player_observations.Charlie: Came off very trustworthy after the clean first mission and maintained a calm, logical table presence, though at times seemed a bit too willing to go along with consensus teams.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as Assassin, staying active but not loud, and used that moderate presence to avoid drawing suspicion while sitting on a key fail opportunity.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, she clearly tried to protect Merlin by spreading her trust around, but the way she balanced trust between Alice and Iris sometimes inadvertently gave Morgana cover.
player_observations.Frank: Looked solidly good throughout, especially after repeated clean appearances on teams, but didn’t always press aggressively enough on the structural case against the repeat-evil suspects.
player_observations.Grace: Sold herself as reliably good early by engineering the clean first mission, then leveraged that trust to sabotage later missions; her willingness to sit on a single fail at the right time was very effective.
player_observations.Henry: As Oberon, his slightly offbeat, less-coordinated table talk actually made him seem more like a confused good player than hidden evil, which let him sneak onto the final failing team.
player_observations.Iris: Played a very convincing Morgana, mirroring good-player reasoning and tone well enough that she stayed in the trusted pool and managed to be included on the decisive failing mission.
